Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Large Scale Synthesis of Hollow Metal Nanospheres: Conversion of Batch Synthesis to Continuous Flow
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is rooted in the development of a large-scale synthesis for the manufacture of highly uniform hollow metal nanospheres for use by the military in potentially contaminated zones of operation, in rural settings with limited access to healthcare laboratories, or in the agricultural field for faster and more affordable detection of lower levels of food-based toxins and pathogens. Furthermore, establishing a source of these next-generation metal nanoparticles at commercially relevant levels of quality and quantity with consistent and predictable performance would pave the way for their expansion into other industries that could also benefit from their advantages, such as photocatalysis, water purification, and photomedicine.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will scale-up the production of hollow metal nanoparticles from the existing small-batch syntheses to a large-scale continuous flow process, with strict standards for the control of their size, shape, and optical response. Large-scale synthesis of highly uniform hollow metal nanospheres with controllable size has not been achieved to date, hampering the use and study of these advanced materials. A high-quality, high-volume production method will position hollow metal nanospheres for rapid commercial adoption in applications where they markedly outperform their solid counterparts, such as in color reporting for lateral flow assays (LFAs), where hollow gold nanospheres can offer a 10-fold improvement in assay sensitivity. The primary objective of the proposed work is to determine the parameters necessary for a high-quality, high-throughput synthesis based on continuous flow, including reactor materials, chamber dimensions, precursor concentrations, flow rates, and reaction times. The major technical hurdle lies in the identification (within a very large parameter space) of suitable conditions for a successful and controlled synthesis; accordingly, a major component of this project is in-depth analysis and characterization of synthesized nanoparticles by optical spectroscopy and electron microscopy. Characterization results will be used to inform iterative reactor improvements. The resulting high throughput reactor will both advance the state of the art of nanomaterial synthesis and enable new research by creating a consistent supply of commercially available hollow nanoparticles with reproducible physical properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project focused on developing a prototype reactor for large scale, high-throughput synthesis of hollow metal nanospheres. Due to their unique structural properties and strong interaction with light, these structures show great promise in applications ranging from chemical catalysis to cancer therapy. To date, high quality samples have been synthesized only in labor-intensive, small-batch processes that are incompatible with large-scale production; simply increasing batch size results in substandard particle quality and price points too high for commercial adoption. By reworking the synthesis from the ground up, a prototype reactor was designed, constructed, and iterated to convert the synthesis from batch to continuous flow format. Precise size and color control were achieved while obtaining ten-fold increases in both product volume and concentration (an effective hundred-fold scale-up in production), reducing the cost of labor by 950% from that of small batch. By building a prototype reactor that supports scalable and low-cost production of a well-controlled product, this project successfully de-risked the primary technical challenge in the commercialization of these advanced nanomaterials.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this Phase I project lies in increasing the availability of high-performance, rationally designed plasmonic components to boost the performance of nano-enabled devices. For example, lateral flow assays (a type of rapid diagnostic test strip) commonly use solid gold nanospheres as color labels but often suffer from low sensitivity. Owing to their plasmonic properties, hollow gold nanoparticles can make test lines up to 20x more discernable, resulting in assays with increased sensitivity for earlier disease detection and prompt case management. To optimize product formulation for this target market, hollow gold nanospheres were functionalized with ligands that increase stability and facilitate antibody attachment. SARS-CoV-2 antibodies were then conjugated to the functionalized particles to create color labels for Covid-19 rapid tests, and successful Covid-19 antigen detection was confirmed. With clear protocols for functionalization and conjugation, and demonstrated scalable output, the hollow gold products are now well-positioned for adoption in lateral flow assays. Establishing market presence in lateral flow will pave the way for the expansion of hollow metal nanospheres into other industries that could also benefit from their advantageous plasmonic properties, such as catalysis, water purification, and therapeutics.


Last Modified: 07/25/2021
Modified by: Sarah A Lindley

By building a prototype reactor that supports scalable and low-cost production of a well-controlled product, this project successfully de-risked the primary technical challenge in the commercialization of these advanced nanomaterials. The broader impact/commercial potential of this Phase I project lies in increasing the availability of high-performance, rationally designed plasmonic components to boost the performance of nano-enabled devices. Establishing market presence in lateral flow will pave the way for the expansion of hollow metal nanospheres into other industries that could also benefit from their advantageous plasmonic properties, such as catalysis, water purification, and therapeutics.
